questions.explanation: Option D is the same as Option A (as rapidly concentrating the bulk of the German army in the West to defeat France before shifting forces to the East before Russia could mobilise was “later known as the Schlieffen Plan”), and we know that the Schlieffen Plan was initially successful due to the successful invasion of Belgium. The Ottoman Empire joined the side of Germany, which we can infer contributed to the German success as it opened new fronts and added a new ally to the coalition. However, option B is distinctly false as the Germans did not get free passage through Belgium (they had to invade Belgium first). Therefore, the correct answer is B, the only option that did not contribute to initial German success.

questions.text: All of the following alliances are correct except
questions.explanation: There is no mention of Japan in the text. Therefore, the correct answer is A. We know that Britain and France were allied together in the Allied Powers (they were part of the Entente), and Austria-Hungary and Germany were allied in the Central Powers, and Romania joined the Allied Powers later (therefore allying with Britain).

questions.text: The most likely reason for German defeat out of the following is
options: Russia’s exit from the war in 1918
The lack of ammunition and supplies for the German military
questions.explanation: The armistice (option C) is not the reason for the German defeat, it is more of a symbol of their defeat. The passage mentions that “with its allies defeated, revolution at home, and the military no longer willing to fight, Kaiser Wilhelm abdicated… and Germany signed an armistice… effectively ending the war”. Thus, of the 3 remaining options, only German military exhaustion is mentioned as one of the reasons for Germany signing the armistice. Russia’s exit from the war (option A) was actually beneficial to the Germans as well. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most likely to be true?

The war lasted more than 4 years

questions.explanation: We do not know when the war actually started, so option B is not the correct answer. There is not enough information in the passage to justify A, and the same goes for D. Therefore, the correct and best answer is C.

situations.text:
The major troop staging and hospital camp in Étaples, France, was identified by researchers as being at the centre of the Spanish flu. The research was published in 1999 by a British team, led by virologist John Oxford. In late 1917, military pathologists reported the onset of a new disease with high mortality that they later recognized as the flu. The overcrowded camp and hospital was an ideal site for the spreading of a respiratory virus. The hospital treated thousands of victims of chemical attacks, and other casualties of war. 100,000 soldiers were in transit through the camp every day. It also was home to a live piggery, and poultry was regularly brought in for food supplies from surrounding villages. Oxford and his team postulated that a significant precursor virus, harboured in birds, mutated and then migrated to pigs kept near the front.
There have been claims that the epidemic originated in the United States. Historian Alfred W. Crosby claimed that the flu originated in Kansas, and popular author John Barry described Haskell County, Kansas, as the point of origin. It has also been claimed that, by late 1917, there had already been a first wave of the epidemic in at least 14 US military camps.
Earlier hypotheses put forward varying points of origin for the epidemic. Some hypothesized that the flu originated in East Asia, a common area for transmission of disease from animals to humans because of dense living conditions. Claude Hannoun, the leading expert on the 1918 flu for the Pasteur Institute, asserted the virus was likely to have come from China. It then mutated in the United States near Boston and from there spread to Brest, France, Europe's battlefields, Europe, and the world with Allied soldiers and sailors as the main disseminators. He considered several other hypotheses of origin, such as Spain, Kansas and Brest, as being possible, but not likely.
Political scientist Andrew Price-Smith published data from the Austrian archives suggesting the influenza had earlier origins, beginning in Austria in early 1917.
In 2014, historian Mark Humphries argued that the mobilization of 96,000 Chinese laborers to work behind the British and French lines might have been the source of the pandemic. Humphries, of the Memorial University of Newfoundland in St. John's, based his conclusions on newly unearthed records. He found archival evidence that a respiratory illness that struck northern China in November 1917 was identified a year later by Chinese health officials as identical to the Spanish flu. A report published in 2016 in the Chinese Medical Association found no evidence that the 1918 virus was imported to Europe via Chinese and Southeast Asian soldiers and workers. It found evidence that the virus had been circulating in the European armies for months and possibly years before the 1918 pandemic.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_flu

questions.text: All of the following presented an ideal setting for the rise of the Spanish flu except
options: The regular visitation of chickens and food supplies
The housing of pigs near the front
The effects of chemical attacks on soldiers
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that “the overcrowded camp and hospital was an ideal site for the spreading of a respiratory virus”. Furthermore, since “Oxford and his team postulated that a significant precursor virus, harboured in birds, mutated and then migrated to pigs”, the fact that “poultry was regularly brought in for food supplies from surrounding villages”, and the hospital and camps were “home to a live piggery” can be inferred to have played a role in the rise of the Spanish flu. Therefore, the correct answer is D, which has no link to creating an ideal setting for the flu as per the text.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most likely to be true according to the passage?
options: The Spanish flu originated in Kansas, United States
The first case of Spanish flu during the war was in Etaples, France
East Asia was an area where the flu transmitted faster and more frequently
The source of the Spanish flu is not definitively known
questions.explanation: Most of the passage is spent debating where the Spanish flu may have originated from, and there is no concrete conclusion to determine where the flu originated from (in the passage). Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: According to the information presented in the passage, all the hypothesised sources of the Spanish flu are based on evidence except
options: Andrew Price-Smith’s proposal that the flu began in Austria
Mark Humphries proposal that the flu began behind British and French lines
Alfred W Crosby’s proposal that the flu began in the United States
The Chinese Medical Association’s proposal that the flu began in Europe
questions.explanation: The final paragraph states that “Humphries … based his conclusions on newly unearthed records”, and that “the Chinese Medical Association… found evidence that the virus had been circulating in the European armies for months”. The 4th paragraph states that “Andrew Price-Smith published data from the Austrian archives suggesting the influenza had earlier origins, beginning in Austria in early 1917”. Thus, while he did use evidence, it was not to back the claim that the flu began in the United States. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: Based on Claude Hannoun’s observations, which of the following places was the Spanish flu most likely to have arisen from?
questions.explanation: The 3rd paragraph states that “Claude Hannoun… asserted the virus was likely to have come from China”. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

The 1918 influenza pandemic (January 1918 – December 1920; colloquially known as Spanish flu) was an unusually deadly influenza pandemic, the first of the two pandemics involving H1N1 influenza virus. It infected 500 million people around the world, including people on remote Pacific islands and in the Arctic. The death toll was at least 50 million, and possibly as high as 100 million (around four percent of Earth's population at the time), making it one of the deadliest epidemics in human history. When an infected person sneezes or coughs, more than half a million virus particles can spread to those nearby. The close quarters and massive troop movements of World War I hastened the pandemic, and probably both increased transmission and augmented mutation. The war may also have increased the lethality of the virus. Some speculate the soldiers' immune systems were weakened by malnourishment, as well as the stresses of combat and chemical attacks, increasing their susceptibility.
A large factor in the worldwide occurrence of this flu was increased travel. Modern transportation systems made it easier for soldiers, sailors, and civilian travellers to spread the disease globally. In the United States, the disease was first observed in Haskell County, Kansas, in January 1918, prompting local doctor Loring Miner to warn the U.S. Public Health Service's academic journal. On 4 March 1918, company cook Albert Gitchell reported sick at Fort Riley, an American military facility that at the time was training American troops during World War I, making him the first recorded victim of the flu. Within days, 522 men at the camp had reported sick. By 11 March 1918, the virus had reached Queens, New York. Failure to take preventive measures in March/April was later criticised.
In August 1918, a more virulent strain appeared simultaneously in Brest, France; in Freetown, Sierra Leone; and in the U.S. in Boston, Massachusetts. The Spanish flu also spread through Ireland, carried there by returning Irish soldiers. The Allies of World War I came to call it the Spanish flu, primarily because the pandemic received greater press attention after it moved from France to Spain in November 1918 through civilian travel. Spain was not involved in the war and had not imposed wartime censorship.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_flu

questions.text: All of the following factors may have contributed to the spread of the pandemic on the front except
options: Effects of chemical attacks on soldiers
The large movement of troops on the front
questions.explanation: The 1st passage states that “when an infected person sneezes or coughs, more than half a million virus particles can spread to those nearby”. It also states that “the close quarters and massive troops movements… hastened the pandemic”, and that “chemical attacks” and “malnourishment” may have increased their susceptibility. Therefore, the correct answer is C, as the passage states that the close quarters MOVEMENT of troops hastened the pandemic; it does not mention anything about close quarters combat.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most likely to be true?

More people died from the virus than actual combat during the war
questions.explanation: If 500 million people were infected, and the death toll is estimated to range from 50 to 100 million, at a minimum, 50/500 * 100 = 10% of the infected population died (thus, a minimum death rate of 10%). Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the 1918 influenza pandemic is most likely to be true according to the information in the passage?
options: The 1918 influenza pandemic was the only one of its kind in history
The 1918 influence pandemic was the deadliest in human history
The 1918 influenza pandemic was more commonly known as the Spanish flu
The 1918 influence pandemic lasted approximately 36 months
questions.explanation: The pandemic lasted from January 1918 to December 1920, which we can calculate to be around 36 months (assuming it started at the start of January and ended at the end of December). Therefore, the correct answer is D. Options A and B have no basis from the passage, and option B is actually disproven by the 1st paragraph which states that the pandemic was “the first of two pandemics involving H1N1 influenza virus”. Option C is incorrect because although it was colloquially known as Spanish flu, we do not know if that means the term was commonplace (all we know is that it was used as an informal term for the pandemic).

questions.text: All of the following are ways in which the virus spread globally except
options: The intimate scene of many military camps
questions.explanation: The 2nd paragraph states that “a large factor in the worldwide occurrence of this flu was increased travel”, because “modern transportation systems made it easier for soldiers, sailors and civilian travellers to spread the disease globally”. Thus, we can eliminate options A, B and D, as ‘non-military movements across borders’ can be inferred to be the same thing as “civilian travellers” moving and spreading the disease “globally”. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

The upper shell of the turtle is called the carapace. The lower shell that encases the belly is called the plastron. The carapace and plastron are joined together on the turtle's sides by bony structures called bridges. The inner layer of a turtle's shell is made up of about 60 bones that include portions of the backbone and the ribs, meaning the turtle cannot crawl out of its shell. The outer layer of the shell is covered by horny scales called scutes that are part of its outer skin, or epidermis. Scutes are made up of the fibrous protein keratin that also makes up the scales of other reptiles. These scutes overlap the seams between the shell bones and add strength to the shell. Some turtles do not have horny scutes; for example, the leatherback sea turtle and the soft-shelled turtles have shells covered with leathery skin instead.
The shape of the shell gives helpful clues about how a turtle lives. Most tortoises have a large, dome-shaped shell that makes it difficult for predators to crush the shell between their jaws. One of the few exceptions is the African pancake tortoise, which has a flat, flexible shell that allows it to hide in rock crevices. Most aquatic turtles have flat, streamlined shells, which aid in swimming and diving. American snapping turtles and musk turtles have small, cross-shaped plastrons that give them more efficient leg movement for walking along the bottom of ponds and streams. Another exception is the Belawan Turtle (also known as Cirebon or West Java), which has sunken-back soft-shell.
The colour of a turtle's shell may vary. Shells are commonly coloured brown, black, or olive green. In some species, shells may have red, orange, yellow, or grey markings, often spots, lines, or irregular blotches. One of the most colourful turtles is the eastern painted turtle, which includes a yellow plastron and a black or olive shell with red markings around the rim.
Tortoises, being land-based, have rather heavy shells. In contrast, aquatic and soft-shelled turtles have lighter shells that help them avoid sinking in water and swim faster with more agility. These lighter shells have large spaces called fontanelles between the shell bones. The shells of leatherback sea turtles are extremely light because they lack scutes and contain many fontanelles.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turtle

questions.text: Which of the following must be true regarding the turtle’s structural characteristics?

questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that “the outer layer of the shell is covered by horny scales called scutes”. Therefore, the correct answer is D, as it is the only option that must be true. The carapace and plastron are joined together by bridges and the inner layer of a turtle’s shell is made of 60 bones including (not excluding) backbone and ribs (therefore, not options A, B or C).

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to contribute to the strength of the turtle’s shell?
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that “these scutes overlap the seams between the shell bones and add strength to the shell”. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: The soft sunken shell is common to all of the following except

questions.text: The reason that turtles and tortoises differ in their shell structure is most likely because

Therefore, the correct answer is A. Options C and D are more specific than option A, meaning they exclude some of the other reasons that a turtle needs a lighter shell, and in terms of option B, we don’t know that turtles must ALWAYS swim.

The grapefruit (Citrus paradisi) is a subtropical citrus tree known for its relatively large and uniquely sour to semi-sweet, somewhat bitter fruit. Grapefruit is a one-of-a-kind citrus hybrid originating in Barbados as an accidental cross between two introduced species – sweet orange (C. sinensis), and pomelo (or shaddock) (C. maxima) – both of which were introduced from Asia in the seventeenth century. When found, it was nicknamed the 'forbidden fruit'. Frequently, it is misidentified as the very similar parent species, pomelo.
The name 'grapefruit' seems to originate with the way that, unlike normal citrus, the fruits of this tree grow in 'clusters', vaguely reminiscent of bunches of grapes.
The genetic origin of the grapefruit is a hybrid mix. One ancestor of the grapefruit was the Jamaican sweet orange (Citrus sinensis), itself an ancient hybrid of Asian origin; the other was the Indonesian pomelo (C. maxima). One story of the fruit's origin is that a certain 'Captain Shaddock' brought pomelo seeds to Jamaica and bred the first fruit, however, it probably originated as a naturally occurring hybrid between the two plants some time after they had been introduced in the Caribbean. However, whilst Barbados claims fame to the first accidental cross, Jamaica claims the grapefruit was first purposely cultivated on its shores.
The hybrid fruit, then called 'the forbidden fruit', was first documented in 1750 by a Welshman, Rev. Griffith Hughes, who described specimens from Barbados in The Natural History of Barbados. Currently, the grapefruit is said to be one of the 'Seven Wonders of Barbados”.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grapefruit

questions.text: According to the passage, which of the following explanations is the most likely reason behind the first creation of grapefruit:
options: Captain Shaddock brought pomelo seeds to Jamaica and bred the first fruit.
Rev Hughes planted a pomelo seed next to the Japanese sweet orange.
After pomelo seeds were introduced on Barbados, an accidental hybrid occurred between pomelo and Jamaican sweet orange to form grapefruit.
Jamaicans purposely created a hybrid between the Indonesian pomelo and the Jamaican sweet orange in order to create grapefruit.
questions.explanation: We know from the 1st paragraph that the grapefruit is “a one-of-a-kind citrus hybrid originating in Barbados as an accidental cross between two introduced species” – “sweet orange” and “pomelo”. We know from the 3rd paragraph that Captain Shaddock brought pomelo seeds to Jamaica and bred the first fruit. The passage also claims it is likely that it probably originated as a naturally occurring hybrid, however of the four options provided, only option C addresses one of these two ideas. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

We can infer that the “C.” stands for Citrus, given that the equivalent name for the grapefruit is “Citrus paradisi”. Therefore, the correct answer is C, as it is the only answer that must be true based on the text (the other options don’t have much or any basis in fact from the information provided in the text).

questions.text: The passage suggests that Grapefruit is different from traditional fruit for the following reasons except:

It originated from a hybrid cross between two other fruit
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that the grapefruit is “uniquely sour to semi-sweet [and] somewhat bitter”, and the 2nd paragraph states that “unlike normal citrus, the fruits of this tree grow in ‘clusters’”. Thus, options A and B can be eliminated. Option D can be eliminated because we know that grapefruit is a “one-of-a-kind hybrid”. Therefore, the correct answer is C, as we know that “it is misidentified frequently to the very similar parent species, pomelo.

questions.text: Which of the following reasons is the most likely explanation as to why the grapefruit is considered to be one of the “Seven Wonders of Barbados”?
options: Grapefruit is the only fruit to originate in Barbados, hence, is very special to the Caribbean island.

The fruit has both an Asian and Indonesian heritage at a time when people did not travel between the two lands, hence, making its existence miraculous and special.

questions.explanation: We do not know if at the time, people did not travel between the two lands of Indonesia and Asia, so option C is unlikely to be correct. We do not know if any of the information presented in option B is correct, as the passage does not mention any of that. We do not have enough information to determine whether option A is correct (we do not know if the grapefruit was the only fruit to grow in Barbados). Therefore, the correct answer is D, as it is an “accidental cross between two species” and “Barbados claims fame to the first accidental cross”.

When the First World War broke out in August 1914, John Monash became a full-time army officer, accepting an appointment as the chief censor in Australia. Monash did not enjoy the job, and was keen for a field command. In September, after the Australian Imperial Force was formed, he was appointed as the commander of the 4th Infantry Brigade, which consisted of four battalions: the 13th, 14th, 15th and 16th. His appointment was met with some protest within the military, in part due to his German and Jewish ancestry, but Monash was supported by numerous high-ranking officers, including James Legge, James McCay and Ian Hamilton, and his appointment stood.
When the first contingent of Australian troops, the 1st Division, sailed in October, the 4th Brigade remained behind. Training was undertaken at Broadmeadows, Victoria, before embarking in December 1914. After arriving in Egypt in January 1915, Monash's brigade established itself at Heliopolis, where it was assigned to the New Zealand and Australian Division under Major General Alexander Godley. After a period of training, in April, the brigade took part in the Gallipoli campaign against the Turks. Assigned the role of divisional reserve, Monash came ashore early on 26 April. The brigade initially defended the line between Pope's Hill and Courtney's Post, and the valley behind this line became known as 'Monash Valley'. There he made a name for himself with his independent decision-making and his organisational ability. As such, he was then promoted to brigadier general in July, although the news was marred by spiteful rumours that were passed in Cairo, Melbourne and London about him being a 'German spy'.
During the August offensive in Gallipoli that was launched by the Allies to break the deadlock on the peninsula, Monash's brigade was to conduct a 'left hook' to the capture of Hill 971, the highest point on the Sari Bair range. On the evening of 6/7 August, the brigade launched its attack, but poor maps, heavy resistance and the mountainous terrain defeated them. Elsewhere, the offensive also stalled, resulting in disaster for the last co-ordinated effort to defeat the Turkish forces on the Gallipoli Peninsula. By mid-August, Monash's brigade was down to just 1,400 men out of the 3,350 it had begun the campaign with.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Monash

questions.text: John Monash was in all of these roles at some point according to the passage, except
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that Monash was the “chief censor”, and he was later appointed as “the commander of the 4th Infantry Brigade” (ie. infantry commander), and at the end of the 2nd paragraph we see that he “was promoted to brigadier general”. Therefore, the correct answer is C, as it is not mentioned in the passage.

questions.text: Monash rose through the ranks of the Australian Imperial Force, most likely because

He had the support of many top officers

He had excellent military organisational skills
questions.explanation: The 2nd paragraph states that Monash “made a name for himself with his independent decision-making and his organisational ability”, and we can infer that this was the reason he was promoted to brigadier general. Although he had the support of many high-ranking officers, that only served to ensure that his appointment stood, not necessarily a reason that he was promoted (according to the passage). Therefore, the correct and best answer is D.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most likely to be true?

Monash’s division was part of the first contingent of Australian troops to set sail

We can infer that these were heavy losses, given that less than half of the men remained. We know that Monash failed in his manoeuvre on the 6/7 August (final paragraph), and we know that the 4th brigade remained behind while the first contingent of Australian troops set sail (2nd paragraph), eliminating option B. Option A could be true, but we don’t have enough information to claim that he was ‘widely’ opposed as such. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.explanation: The final paragraph states that “poor maps, heavy resistance and the mountainous terrain defeated [Monash’s brigade]”. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

Rainbows can be observed whenever there are water drops in the air and sunlight shining from behind the observer at a low altitude angle. Because of this, rainbows are usually seen in the western sky during the morning and in the eastern sky during the early evening. The most spectacular rainbow displays happen when half the sky is still dark with raining clouds and the observer is at a spot with clear sky in the direction of the sun. The result is a luminous rainbow that contrasts with the darkened background. During such good visibility conditions, the larger but fainter secondary rainbow is often visible. It appears about 10° outside of the primary rainbow, with inverse order of colours.
The rainbow effect is also commonly seen near waterfalls or fountains. In addition, the effect can be artificially created by dispersing water droplets into the air during a sunny day. Rarely, a moonbow, lunar rainbow or night time rainbow, can be seen on strongly moonlit nights. As human visual perception for colour is poor in low light, moonbows are often perceived to be white.
It is difficult to photograph the complete semicircle of a rainbow in one frame, as this would require an angle of view of 84°. For a 35 mm camera, a wide-angle lens with a focal length of 19 mm or less would be required. Now that software for stitching several images into a panorama is available, images of the entire arc and even secondary arcs can be created fairly easily from a series of overlapping frames.
From above the earth such as in an aeroplane, it is sometimes possible to see a rainbow as a full circle. This phenomenon can be confused with the glory phenomenon, but a glory is usually much smaller, covering only 5–20°.
The sky inside a primary rainbow is brighter than the sky outside of the bow. This is because each raindrop is a sphere and it scatters light over an entire circular disc in the sky. The radius of the disc depends on the wavelength of light, with red light being scattered over a larger angle than blue light. Over most of the disc, scattered light at all wavelengths overlaps, resulting in white light which brightens the sky. At the edge, the wavelength dependence of the scattering gives rise to the rainbow.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainbow

questions.text: The characteristics of a secondary rainbow include all of the following except
options: The secondary rainbow is a less visible than the main rainbow
Opposite order of colours to the main rainbow
The secondary rainbow is larger than the primary
It is visible around 10° under the primary rainbow
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that “during such good visibility conditions, the larger but fainter secondary rainbow is often visible” and “it appears about 10o outside of the primary rainbow, with inverse order of colours”. Therefore, the correct answer is D (as the secondary rainbow appear 10o outside not under the primary rainbow).

questions.text: All of the following are true except
options: A rainbow is always naturally formed
A rainbow can form in the presence of airborn water droplets and sunlight
A rainbow can be viewed from multiple angles
A rainbow can be perceived as white at certain times of day
questions.explanation: The 2nd paragraph states that “the [rainbow effect] can be artificially created by dispersing water droplets into the air during a sunny day”. Therefore, the correct answer is A, as we know that rainbows do not always have to be naturally formed. A moonbow (night time rainbow) is often perceived to be white during the night, and we know from the 4th paragraph that you can see a rainbow from above Earth as well. Thus, options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be false?
options: Rainbows can exist as full circles
Any 35mm camera would be able to photograph the entire semicircle of a rainbow in a single frame
It is quite easy to capture a full semicircle rainbow

questions.explanation: We know from the 3rd paragraph that “for a 35mm camera, a wide-angle lens with a focal length of 19mm or less would be required” to see photograph the complete semicircle of a rainbow in one frame. Thus, not just any 35mm can be used. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be true based on the information in the text?
options: Humans are never able to see moonbows in colours other than white
Moonbows and rainbows are the same thing
The glory phenomenon is the same as a rainbow
The colour white is included in the rainbow as seen during the day
questions.explanation: We know from the 2nd paragraph that moonbows are lunar rainbows or rainbows seen at night – thus we can infer that they are the same thing, it’s just that since “human visual perception for colour is poor in low light, moonbows are often perceived to be white”. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text:
With his book Hind Swaraj (1909) Gandhi, aged 40, declared that British rule was established in India with the co-operation of Indians and had survived only because of this co-operation. If Indians refused to co-operate, British rule would collapse and swaraj would come.
In February 1919, Gandhi cautioned the Viceroy of India with a cable communication that if the British were to pass the Rowlatt Act, he would appeal to Indians to start civil disobedience. The British government ignored him and passed the law, stating it would not yield to threats. The satyagraha civil disobedience followed, with people assembling to protest the Rowlatt Act. On 30 March 1919, British law officers opened fire on an assembly of unarmed people, peacefully gathered, participating in satyagraha in Delhi.
People rioted in retaliation. On 6 April 1919, a Hindu festival day, he asked a crowd to remember not to injure or kill British people, but to express their frustration with peace, to boycott British goods and burn any British clothing they owned. He emphasised the use of non-violence to the British and towards each other, even if the other side uses violence. Communities across India announced plans to gather in greater numbers to protest. Government warned him to not enter Delhi. Gandhi defied the order. On 9 April, Gandhi was arrested.
People rioted. On 13 April 1919, protestors including women with children gathered in an Amritsar park, and a British officer named Reginald Dyer surrounded them and ordered his troops to fire on them. The resulting Jallianwala Bagh massacre (or Amritsar massacre) of hundreds of Sikh and Hindu civilians enraged the subcontinent, but was cheered by some Britons and parts of the British media as an appropriate response. Gandhi in Ahmedabad, on the day after the massacre in Amritsar, did not criticise the British and instead criticised his fellow countrymen for not exclusively using love to deal with the hate of the British government. Gandhi demanded that people stop all violence, stop all property destruction, and went on a fast-to-the-death to pressure Indians to stop their rioting.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Ghandi

questions.text: Based on the text, the swaraj is most likely
options: The end of British rule in India
questions.explanation: Although the text does not state anything, we can infer from the phrase “if Indians refused to co-operate, British rule would collapse and swaraj would come”, that swaraj is most likely equivalent to the end of British rule. It is very unlikely to be options A, C and D given the context of the passage. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: Ghandi was most likely to support which of the following actions?
options: Marching on Delhi armed with weapons
Burning down British buildings and establishments
Peacefully protect, but if the other side uses violence, engage in violence too
Avoid purchasing British food and drinks
questions.explanation: Ghandi “emphasised the use of non-violence to the British and towards each other, even if the other side uses violence”, so he would most likely opposed to options A, B and C. Ghandi however did support the “boycott [of] British goods”. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: According to the information in the passage, the Amritsar massacre was an ultimate consequence of all of the following except
options: The protesting actions of Hindu and Sikh citizens
The violent responses and actions of Reginald Dyer and his troops
The non-violent approach that Ghandi promoted
questions.explanation: We know that the Amritsar massacre involved “rioters”, whom which we can infer to be Hindu and Sikh citizens given that they were the victims of the massacre. We also know that it involved Reginald Dyer’s orders for his troops to fire on the protestors. We can infer that “people rioted” following Ghandi’s arrest given the context in the passage as well. There is no information on whether the protestors were non-violent or violent, so we cannot say whether option C is true. Therefore, the correct answer is C

questions.text: All of the following responses from Ghandi to the massacre are false except
options: He advocated for violent retaliation amongst the Indian people
He demanded that those across the subcontinent rise up
He stopped eating to influence a non-violent approach from the people
He criticised the British’s over the top and unnecessary actions against his people
questions.explanation: We know that Ghandi “did not criticise the British” and “demanded that people stop all violence”. Thus, options A and D are incorrect. Option B is not mentioned in the passage, so we don’t know. However, we know that Ghandi “went on a fast-to-the-death to pressure Indians to stop their rioting”. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text:
A carbon tax is a tax levied on the carbon content of fuels (transport and energy sector) and, like carbon emissions trading, is a form of carbon pricing. The term carbon tax is also used to refer to a carbon dioxide equivalent tax, the latter of which is quite similar but can be placed on any type of greenhouse gas like carbon dioxide.
As of 2018, at least 27 countries and subnational units have implemented carbon taxes. Research shows that carbon taxes effectively reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Economists generally argue that carbon taxes are the most efficient and effective way to curb climate change, with the least adverse effects on the economy.
When a hydrocarbon fuel such as coal, petroleum, or natural gas is burnt, its carbon is converted to carbon dioxide (CO2) and other compounds of carbon. CO2 is a heat-trapping greenhouse gas which causes global warming, which damages the environment and human health. Since greenhouse gas emissions from the combustion of fossil fuels are closely related to the carbon content of the respective fuels, this negative externality can be compensated for by taxing the carbon content of fossil fuels at any point in the product cycle of the fuel.
Carbon taxes offer a potentially cost-effective means of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. From an economic perspective, carbon taxes are a type of Pigovian tax and help to address the problem of emitters of greenhouse gases not facing the full social cost of their actions. To prevent them being regressive taxes carbon tax revenues can be spent on low-income groups.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_tax#Australia

questions.text: All of the following are theoretical examples of carbon taxes except
options: A tax on the amount of coal burnt by factories
A tax on cars that produced CO2 emissions
A tax on cows which produce methane gas
A tax on the amount of natural gas used to operate machinery
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that “the term carbon tax is also used to refer to a carbon dioxide equivalent tax… that can be placed on any type of greenhouse gas like carbon dioxide”. Thus, option B is a potential example, and since coal and natural gas produce CO2 (3rd paragraph), options A and D are too. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely the reason for countries choosing not to implement carbon taxes?
options: They do not believe in the effects of climate change
Their economies are not strong enough to survive a carbon tax
They do not know how to spend the money generated by the tax
questions.explanation: The 2nd paragraph states that economist generally argue the fact that carbon taxes have the least adverse effects on the economy, however this implies that there are some adverse effects on the economy. Thus, of the four options, only C refers to the economic considerations of a country. Therefore, the correct answer is C. Option B could be true, however compared with option C it is not as strong, given that we don’t really have any information as to how the carbon tax is linked to climate change.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely the social purpose of a carbon tax?
options: To make big emitters of CO2 understand the environmental costs of their actions
To punish those who emit large amounts of CO2
To help low-income groups with the money raised
To prompt big emitters of greenhouse gases to rethink their emission levels
questions.explanation: The final paragraph mentions how carbon taxes help “address the problem of emitters of greenhouse gases not facing the full social cost of their actions” – thus we can infer that one of the purposes of the tax is to ensure that these emitters face the full social cost of their actions. Option A focuses on the environmental cost of these emitters’ actions, which is not mentioned, and option B is not mentioned either. Option C is not a part of the carbon tax (more like a suggested use for the revenue gained). Therefore, the correct answer is D, as it seems the most reasonable based off this information.

questions.text: All of the following are potential consequences of not implementing a carbon text except
options: Greenhouse gas emissions will rise and increase in intensity
Big CO2-emitting companies will continue to use fossil fuels
Society will ignore the problem of carbon emissions
questions.explanation: We know that CO2 is a greenhouse gas and contributes to global warming, so we can eliminate options A and B. We can infer that because the tax is a deterrent for emitters of greenhouse gases, if the carbon tax was not implemented, these emitters would not be deterred. Thus, we can eliminate option C (since we know fossil fuels emit greenhouse gases from the 2nd paragraph). Therefore, the correct answer is D, as society’s role in reducing carbon emissions is not mentioned in the passage.

situations.text:
Renewable energy is energy that is collected from renewable resources, which are naturally replenished on a human timescale, such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves, and geothermal heat. Renewable energy often provides energy in four important areas: electricity generation, air and water heating/cooling, transportation, and rural (off-grid) energy services.
At the national level, at least 30 nations around the world have worked hard to achieve renewable energy contributing more than 20 percent of energy supply. National renewable energy markets are projected to continue to grow strongly in the coming decade and beyond. Some places and at least two countries, Iceland and Norway, generate all their electricity using renewable energy already, and many other countries have the set a goal to reach 100% renewable energy in the future. At least 47 nations around the world already have over 50 percent of electricity from renewable resources. Renewable energy resources exist over wide geographical areas, in contrast to fossil fuels, which are concentrated in a limited number of countries. Rapid deployment of renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies is resulting in significant energy security, climate change mitigation, and economic benefits. In international public opinion surveys there is strong support for promoting renewable sources such as solar power and wind power.
While many renewable energy projects are large-scale, renewable technologies are also suited to rural and remote areas and developing countries, where energy is often crucial in human development. As most of renewable energy technologies provide electricity, renewable energy deployment is often applied in conjunction with further electrification, which has several benefits: electricity can be converted to heat (where necessary generating higher temperatures than fossil fuels), can be converted into mechanical energy with high efficiency, and is clean at the point of consumption. In addition, electrification with renewable energy is more efficient and therefore leads to significant reductions in primary energy requirements.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_energy

questions.text: All of the following could be examples of renewable energy based on the text except
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that renewable energy is collected from renewable resources, such as sunlight, wind and waves. The final sentence of the 2nd paragraph also mentioned “renewable sources such as solar power and wind power”. Thus, options A, B and D are correct for sure. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be true?
options: In the future, all countries will have 100% renewable energy
Transitioning to renewable energy sources is difficult
Renewable energy is accessible for all countries
Renewable energy is cheaper than using fossil fuels
questions.explanation: Since only at least 30 nations have renewable energy contributing 20% of energy supply, and they worked hard to do so, we can infer that the transition to renewable energy is difficult, otherwise the supply would most likely be greater. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: The benefits of using renewable energy include all of the following except
options: They are widespread compared to fossil fuels
questions.explanation: The 2nd paragraph states that “rapid deployment of renewable energy… is resulting in significant energy security, climate change mitigation, and economic benefits”. Thus, options A and D can be eliminated. The 2nd paragraph also states that “renewable energy resources exist over wide geographical areas, in contrast to fossil fuels, which are concentrated in a limited number of countries”. Thus, option C is eliminated. Therefore, the correct answer is B, as we only know that renewable energy leads to the mitigation of climate change, not necessarily an end to it.

questions.text: According to the passage, rural communities are most likely to benefit from renewable energy through which of the following ways?
options: Electricity from renewable energy can also be converted into heat sources
Electricity from renewable energy can be used to power machinery
Renewable energy can further accelerate the development of the region
Renewable energy can help reduce primary energy requirements
questions.explanation: The last paragraph states that “renewable technologies are also suited to rural and remote areas and developing countries, where energy is often crucial in human development”. Thus, we can infer that renewable energy can help improve the human development of the region (and thus accelerate the development of the region). Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text:
Following his assertion of independence from the khan, 'Veliki Kniaz' Ivan III of Muscovy started to use the title of Tsar regularly in diplomatic relations with the West. From about 1480, he was designated as 'imperator' in his Latin correspondence, as 'keyser' in his correspondence with the Swedish regent, as 'kejser' in his correspondence with the Danish king, Teutonic Knights, and the Hanseatic League. Ivan's son Vasily III continued using these titles. Sigismund von Herberstein observed that the titles of 'kaiser' and 'imperator' were attempts to render the Russian term 'tsar' into German and Latin, respectively.
This was related to Russia's growing ambitions to become an Orthodox 'Third Rome', after the Fall of Constantinople. The Muscovite ruler was recognized as an emperor by Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I in 1514. However, the first Russian ruler to be formally crowned as Tsar of All Ruswas Ivan IV, until then known as Grand Prince of all the Russias. Some foreign ambassadors—namely, Herberstein (in 1516 and 1525), Daniel Printz a Buchau (in 1576 and 1578) and Just Juel (in 1709)—indicated that the word 'tsar' should not be translated as 'emperor', because it is applied by Russians to David, Solomon and other Biblical kings, who are simple reges. On the other hand, Jacques Margeret, a bodyguard of False Demetrius I, argued that the title of 'tsar' is more honorable for Muscovites than 'kaiser' or 'king' exactly because it was God and not some earthly potentate who ordained to apply it to David, Solomon, and other kings of Israel. Samuel Collins, a court physician to Tsar Alexis in 1659-66, styled the latter 'Great Emperor', commenting that 'as for the word Czar, it has so near relation to Cesar... that it may well be granted to signify ‘Emperor’. The Russians would have it to be a higher title than King, and yet they call David Czar, and our kings, Kirrols, probably from Carolus Quintus, whose history they have among them'.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsar#Russia

questions.text: All of the following are examples of titles held by Russian rulers except:
options: Grand Prince of all the Russias
questions.explanation: In the 1st paragraph, we see the title of Tsar used in diplomatic relations with the West, and the terms Kaiser and Imperator were attempts to render the Russian term ‘tsar’ into German and Latin languages. In the 2nd paragraph, we see that Ruswas Ivan IV was known as Grand Prince of all the Russias until he was formally crowned Tsar. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: What is the most likely explanation as to why Veliki Kniaz specifically used the words ‘imperator’, ‘keyser’ and ‘kejser’ in his correspondences in Latin, Swedish and Danish respectively (Why did he not simply use the same title in each correspondence):
options: Kniaz wanted to be unique and ensure that he held many titles internationally.
The languages of Swedish and Danish are very similar, except in Danish the ‘y’ is ‘j’, therefore Kniaz changed the word.
They were attempts to render the Russian word ‘Tsar’ in the vocabulary of each language respectively, hence, the word changed to better match the language.
Kniaz was still experimenting with his title, and he wanted to have many options open.
questions.explanation: Since we know that the term ‘kaiser’ and ‘imperator’ were attempts to render the Russian term ‘tsar’ into German and Latin respectively (1st paragraph), we can infer that the terms ‘kejser’ and ‘keyser’ were also attempts to render the term ‘tsar’ into the languages of those regions. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: What is the most likely explanation as to why Velik Kinaz first adopted the title of ‘Tsar’?
options: To distance himself from the khan and proclaim his independence
To show that he is the ‘Emperor’ of Russian, the higher status representing his higher powers and abilities.
So other rulers in different countries would learn to fear him because ‘Tsar’ sounds very similar to ‘Cesar’.
To make his mark on history so that his reign would not be forgotten.
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that “following his assertion of independence from the khan”, ‘Veliki Kniaz’ Ivan III of Muscovy began using the title of Tsar. Thus, we can infer that the adoption of the title was most likely an act of independence and an attempt to differentiate himself from the khan that previously ruled. Therefore, the correct answer is A. The other 3 options cannot be inferred to the same extent based on this information.

questions.text: In the passage, it is suggested that all the following points about the Russian use of the word ‘Tsar’ is true except:
options: Ivan Muscovsky was one of the first Russian rulers to actively promote a new title for himself in foreign relations.
Ivan IV was the first to officially be crowned ‘Tsar’ when he took the throne.
Jacques Margeret argued that the title of ‘Tsar’ is more honorable than “King” because of its divine connotations.
Just Juel argued that the word ‘Tsar’ is synonymous to emperor and King, and should be used interchangeably.
questions.explanation: Just Juel argued that the word ‘tsar’ “should not be translated as ‘emperor’”, and thus we can infer that Just Juel did not believe that the terms ‘tsar’ and ‘emperor’ were synonymous/used interchangeably. Therefore, the correct answer is D.
